intro: Boehmeria lohuiensis, commonly known as the Lohu Island nettle, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Urticaceae, which includes various species of nettles. The plant is characterized by its soft, hairy leaves and small, inconspicuous flowers. It is often found in moist, shaded environments such as forests and wetlands. Its fibrous stems have been traditionally used for making textiles and paper in some regions.
